title: The Goldman Sachs dream ticket turned nightmare
text:
One event to start: We've confirmed our first full panel for Due Diligence Live on October 12 in London. Join DD's Rob Smith as he hosts a discussion on short selling in today's market. Look out for more news about the programme in the coming weeks. To gain early-bird access to the event and find more details go here.

In today's newsletter:

  • Goldman's hung LBO financing

  • OneWeb-Eutelsat deal analysis

The end of cheap money bites Goldman

The cost of living crisis has claimed an unexpected group of victims: financiers at Goldman Sachs.

Their decision to underwrite the £5bn+ debt package backing the leveraged buyout of British supermarket Morrisons has backfired spectacularly. Inflationary pressures on the grocer's business have made these bonds and loans harder to shift to skittish investors.

We doubt few will cry over Wall Street's masters of the universe facing the prospect of lower bonuses, but the unravelling of the Morrisons LBO also serves as a vivid illustration of how the excesses of the cheap-money era are coming back to bite the world's biggest banks.

Once a dream ticket for the lenders, DD's Rob Smith and Kaye Wiggins explain how it has turned into a growing nightmare that has cost them hundreds of millions of pounds.

Back in the boom times of 2021, Goldman tripled-down on Clayton, Dubilier & Rice's take-private of British supermarket chain Morrisons.

It served as the US private equity firm's M&A adviser and led the financing for the deal. Goldman took on further exposure through a substantial investment in the group's preference shares, which were made through its principal investing unit's special situations fund.

But as the market turned, Goldman and the other 15 underwriters were left holding the bag.

These banks have taken a gross loss of more than £200mn on selling the debt this year, according to Financial Times calculations. More than £2bn of the deal's loans are still hung on their balance sheets — marking it to market leaves a further £400mn hole.

One loan fund manager has called it “the biggest fiasco since the Boots LBO”, referring to the 2007 buyout of the UK pharmacy chain that left banks holding billions of pounds of debt as credit markets turned.

Some bankers say there was little Goldman and others could do when the markets turned. “None of us are happy about losing money on a trade like this, but particularly given the size I really do think it's been de-risked incredibly well given the market,” said one of the deal's underwriters.

Others are more scathing.

“It's just very un-Goldman,” said one rival banker. “They're usually ahead when the tide starts turning.”

Those will be hard words to hear at Goldman, where leveraged finance bankers rule the roost. Chief executive David Solomon cut his teeth working for junk bond king Michael Milken and chief financial officer Denis Coleman used to run the European debt unit that signed the Morrisons deal.

With Morrisons' senior debt now trading at 80 pence in the pound, it would also be interesting to know where Goldman has marked the grocer's £1.3bn of riskier preference shares, which it split equally with private markets giant Ares Management. And that's before you get to the question of what CD&R's equity is now worth.

For some observers, the deal is a symptom of the sense of complacency across Wall Street that a long period of low interest rates induced.

“It was an aggressive deal in a hot market,” said one senior debt banker. “You can see why it happened: for years there was no reward for being conservative.”

OneWeb/Eutelsat: ‘Ground control to Major Dom'

These days, Dominic Cummings can usually be found fuming about the UK government in his Substack newsletter or on Twitter. But not long ago, he was pulling the strings of Boris Johnson's government and trying to execute the country's exit from the European Union.

Among the things the UK lost access to after Brexit was the €10bn Galileo navigation system developed for the EU by European Space Agency.*

Keen for the UK to have access to next generation space technology, Cummings found a solution: pouring $500mn into a bankrupt low earth orbit start-up called OneWeb.

OneWeb, which went bust in 2020 after SoftBank refused to keep injecting capital into the business, was taken out of Chapter 11 by the UK government and Bharti Global, a unit of Indian tycoon Sunil Bharti Mittal's conglomerate.

But, the space race isn't cheap and OneWeb's cash needs are enormous.

OneWeb was a pioneer in building a satellite constellation of low-earth orbit, which can beam internet to the most remote parts of the world. But its technology has been leapfrogged by newer privately funded entrants such as Elon Musk's Starlink, a unit of SpaceX.

For what was supposed to be such a strategic move, the UK government was unwilling to keep pouring money in. Since emerging out of bankruptcy, OneWeb has raised new funds from a number of parties including SoftBank and France's Eutelsat — but the UK did not participate.

That brings us to the news this week with Eutelsat, a legacy satellite operator, nearing a deal to buy OneWeb. The deal will be structured as a merger of equals. The hope is that Eutelsat, which the French government owns 20 per cent of, will be able to cover OneWeb's investment needs and emerge over time as a challenger to Starlink and others.

But the deal raises a number of complicated questions. First, shareholders — who own Eutelsat for its stable cash flow and dividends — hate the deal, as Lex explains. Eutelsat shares fell more than 17 per cent on Monday.

Second, the UK government is set to retain special rights in OneWeb including on its customers and have a board seat in the combined group. With the French government also set to have a board seat, along with Mittal, the prospect for governance mishaps looms large.

And finally, the deal means that within a short space of time the UK has lost two domestic space champions: Satellite communications group Inmarsat, which was acquired in 2019 by private equity and sold to US-based Viasat last year pending competition approvals, and now OneWeb.

*This line has been amended since original publication

Job moves

Volkswagen chief executive Herbert Diess was ousted on Friday and replaced by Porsche's chief executive Oliver Blume. Go deeper here.

Evergrande's chief executive, Xia Haijun and chief financial officer Pan Darong have resigned after an internal investigation found they were involved in a scheme causing banks to claim more than $2bn from a subsidiary.

Kuwait wealth fund KIA has appointed Hussain Al-Halabi to replace Saleh Al-Ateeqi as head of the investment authority's London arm. He will join the firm immediately from one of its subsidiaries, St Martin's Property Group.

Drew Goldman, who heads advisory and investment banking coverage, is leaving Deutsche Bank, according to an internal memo. Bruce Evans, who is co-head of M&A, will assume Goldman's responsibilities in the Americas region.

Citi has hired Uday Malhotra from Bank of America to co-head its EMEA loans and leverage finance business.

Vince McMahon stepped down as CEO and chair of World Wrestling Entertainment on Friday amid reports of alleged sexual misconduct revealed by the Wall Street Journal.

Former White House press secretary Jay Carney is joining Airbnb in September to head communications and public policy. Carney joins from Amazon where he led the lobbying and media relations team for the past seven years.

Smart reads

The taming of Citigroup: Once a financial supermarket with far-flung operations too unwieldy to manage, Citigroup's new CEO Jane Fraser is succeeding in reining in the banking giant and winning support from shareholders, the FT reports.

The Oligarch's Moneyman: When Russian oligarchs were sanctioned this spring, it blew up the careful dance of Pamplona Capital's Alex Knaster, as he traversed western finance and the windfalls from the Soviet Union's collapse, Bloomberg reports.

China's Godfather of Education: New Oriental Education, once among a crop of soaring publicly-listed Chinese technology disrupters, is now struggling to stay afloat and an emblem of global investors' retreat as president Xi Jinping presses a “common prosperity” agenda, according to the FT.
